docs.snippet: LOW--Josiah O. III, 75, died peacefully on June 20, 2014, surrounded by his family and with his German shepherd by his side. Joe was born to Katherine and Josiah O. Low Jr. on June 5, 1939 in Detroit, Michigan. He worked his way through Williams C...
docs.lead_paragraph: LOW--Josiah O. III, 75, died peacefully on June 20, 2014, surrounded by his family and with his German shepherd by his side. Joe was born to Katherine and Josiah O. Low Jr. on June 5, 1939 in Detroit, Michigan. He worked his way through Williams College graduating in 1961. Joe built a career as an investment banker, first at Merrill Lynch and then at Donaldson, Lufkin, & Jenrette where he led the corporate finance group for 15 years. On Wall Street he was known for his unbending integrity and unending interest in others. Colleagues he worked with 40 years ago cite his mentorship as critical to their own success. Many also recall that he kept a saddle in the trunk of his car. After leaving DLJ, he continued to serve on the board of a number of companies, including Centex Development, CoStar Group, and Rosetta Resources. In 2002, he joined Catterton Partners as a Senior Advisor. He advised CEO's of Fortune 500 Companies and later helped friends and local business people expand their businesses or find a path out of trouble. If you came in contact with Joe, you remembered him with a smile. He blew his nose with a trumpet that turned heads, and he sang along to opera and Willie Nelson, whether or not he knew the words. He entertained children with his cowboy yip and songs about cowpies. He disliked mini-golf, "a bastardization of the game", cilantro and the snapping of gum. Joe grew up working as a ranch hand at French Creek, his family's guest ranch in Wyoming's Platte River Valley. His love for the West was infectious. He introduced hundreds of friends and colleagues to Wyoming with visits to the A Bar A, a ranch down the valley from French Creek. Joe was unexpectedly friendly and sincerely interested in everyone he met. Ordering at a restaurant was always time consuming because Joe needed to learn the name and background of the waiter -- some connection could always be found. By the time dessert came, he was often sitting at another table with people he had just met. To his five grandchildren, he was Poppa Joe. The grandfather who hid a radio under your pillow so you could listen to the Giants game at night. The patient teacher who poured a little extra root beer float in your glass to demonstrate the concept of principal and interest. He did not allow whining or weak handshakes. He was irreverent, generous, joyful and loving. He let you ride the ATV despite what your parents said. He paid his six year-old granddaughter to paint his toenails. To his three sons, he was a father who arose every morning at 5:30 to provide his children with opportunities and experiences that he never had. He encouraged his sons to pursue their passions, put together a plan, and then to "get it done." He was an investor in their dreams, their advisor, and friend. Joe loved the outdoors and gave generously to the Williamstown Rural Lands Foundation. He planted hundreds of trees and was often seen mowing the meadows surrounding his home in Williamstown. He had an extensive collection of John Deere tractors. When he ran out of space for more tractors, he gave them away to friends, because "everyone needs a tractor." He shared his passion for western music by setting up concerts in Williamstown. At these events, he would often join his hero Don Edwards on stage for a duet, despite the cringes of his wife and children. He served as a Williams class agent for many years and was selected to lead his class's procession at their 50th reunion. Joe was the lead donor in the purchase and renovation of the Sand Springs Recreation Center, a historic aquatic center that now serves as community gathering place and swim academy in Williamstown. He set up a foundation to fund free swim lessons so that no child would ever be afraid of the water. He loved opera, American antiques, and Western art. His favorite fashion statement was a young woman with a ponytail poking out of the back of a baseball cap. Joe was unbeatable in horseshoes, a devious opponent in gin rummy, and he could still out drive his sons well into his 70's. He gave his wife old pick-up trucks for her birthday. Children he barely knew named stuffed animals after him. He was loved by so many. There is now a giant hole in our hearts that we will all try to fill with the openness and generosity that was Joe Low. Joe is survived by Penny (Ireland) his loving wife of 50 years, three sons Tad (Alisa), Timothy (Loriann), and Jeffrey (Stacey), five grandchildren: Ryan, Julia, Aidan, Nicholas, and Eliza, his sister Katherine, and two brothers David and Charles, and numerous nieces and nephews. There will be a private family memorial service. Gifts in Joe's honor may be made to the Williamstown Rural Lands Foundation Williamstown, MA 01267 or simply through unexpected kindness or interest in another person's life.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOW, JOSIAH O

docs.snippet: Ben Williams sacrificed his salary as a teacher for six months so he could prepare for the World Cup. On Sunday, it paid off. Williams became the first Australian referee to control a second-round match at a World Cup during the game between Costa...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ben Williams sacrificed his salary as a teacher for six months so he could prepare for the World Cup. On Sunday, it paid off. Williams became the first Australian referee to control a second-round match at a World Cup during the game between Costa Rica and Greece.

headline.main: BRAZIL BEAT: Teacher Makes History for Australia
headline.print_headline: BRAZIL BEAT: Teacher Makes History for Australia

docs.snippet: Unlike the relatively restrained players in American sports leagues, goal scorers at the World Cup unleash celebrations ranging from joyous to defiant to bizarre....
docs.lead_paragraph: Unlike the relatively restrained players in American sports leagues, goal scorers at the World Cup unleash celebrations ranging from joyous to defiant to bizarre.
docs.abstract: World Cup in Brazil has produced dizzying number of goals, and wonderful variety of celebrations and outbursts from triumphant players; exuberance comes as refreshing change of pace from staid culture of sports in United States, where players are expected to remain stoic after scoring, and fines are issued for those who go too far.

headline.seo: World Cup 2014: Goal Celebrations in Soccer Are Always Colorful
headline.main: Cup Overflows: You Won’t See Joy Like This in the End Zone
headline.print_headline: Cup Overflows: You Won’t See Joy Like This in the End Zone

byline.contributor: Mary Pilon contributed reporting from New York, and Tim Rohan from St. Louis.

docs.snippet: In its bicentennial year, “The Star-Spangled Banner” will be performed in a manner Francis Scott Key might recognize....
docs.lead_paragraph: In its bicentennial year, “The Star-Spangled Banner” will be performed in a manner Francis Scott Key might recognize.
docs.abstract: Baritone Thomas Hampson is performing Star-Spangled Banner at Library of Congress to celebrate song's bicentennial year, but it may not be quite as familiar as most Americans expect; anthem is being performed the way it might have sounded 200 years ago, when Francis Scott Key wrote new lyrics to old British melody aboard ship in Baltimore's harbor.

headline.seo: ‘The Star-Spangled Banner’ Has Changed a Lot in 200 Years
headline.main: How the National Anthem Has Unfurled
headline.print_headline: How the National Anthem Has Unfurled

docs.snippet: The jookin master Lil Buck is taking his Memphis dance skills to new levels and new audiences, from Aspen to Las Vegas to Lincoln Center....
docs.lead_paragraph: The jookin master Lil Buck is taking his Memphis dance skills to new levels and new audiences, from Aspen to Las Vegas to Lincoln Center.
docs.abstract: Dancer Lil Buck, born Charles Riley, is taking his Memphis dance skills to new heights and new audiences; he has gone from busking on Santa Monica Pier to artist-in-residence at Aspen Institute; Riley is set to perform at City Center in New York and Works & Process series at Guggenheim Museum; he is also guest judge on Fox's So You Think You Can Dance.
